hero.title: TAKETORA
hero.subtitle: Antique Shop in Kyoto
hero.body:
Discover timeless treasures on Kyoto's historic Gojo-zaka slope.
Japanese antiques, traditional crafts, anime figures & Pokémon cards —
a curated collection of Japan's finest, past and present.

story.title: TAKETORA
story.p1: Gojo-zaka — the slope leading to the iconic Kiyomizu-dera temple — has been the heart of Kyoto's ceramics and crafts culture for centuries.
story.p2: Taketora brings together the best of Japanese culture under one roof: from traditional antiques and folk crafts that embody centuries of artisanship, to anime figures and Pokémon cards that represent Japan's vibrant pop culture today.
story.p3: Discover authenticity. Embrace tradition. Experience TAKETORA.

antiques.label: Antiques & Traditional Crafts
antiques.title: Japanese Antiques
antiques.subtitle: Authentic antiques and traditional crafts from the heart of Kyoto.
antiques.body1: Located on Gojo-zaka — the famed pottery slope leading to Kiyomizu-dera temple — Taketora offers a carefully curated selection of authentic Japanese antiques and traditional crafts.
antiques.body2: From Kiyomizu-yaki ceramics and tea ceremony utensils to hanging scrolls and vintage folk art, each piece carries the spirit of Japanese craftsmanship spanning centuries. Whether you're a seasoned collector or discovering Japanese antiques for the first time, our English-speaking staff will guide you through every piece's history and significance.

categories.folk: Folk Crafts & Vintage Items (ironware, tansu, woodwork)
categories.art: Art & Calligraphy (hanging scrolls, ukiyo-e, folding screens)

visit.mainBody: Our Kyoto boutiques sit just below Kiyomizu-dera in the Higashiyama district, tucked between the temple paths, preserved stone streets, and traditional townhouses. As you make your way down from the Kiyomizu stage toward Ninenzaka, Sannenzaka, and Gion, you can easily stop by Taketora to pick up premium collectibles.
visit.neighborhoodBody: From Kiyomizu-dera to Fushimi Inari and Gion, our locations sit along the natural path most visitors walk when exploring Kyoto.
